Based on your preferences and the information provided, I would recommend 'Big Fish' as a captivating and emotionally resonant film from 2003 that combines elements of literature, drama, and romance.

Another recommendation could be 'Hotel Rwanda', another critically acclaimed movie released in 2004. This film is an intense and emotional account of the Rwandan genocide, which took place between April 6 and July 19, 1994.

For a different kind of recommendation, I would suggest watching 'A Little Princess'. This classic 19th-century novel from 1860 by Charles Dickens tells the story of a young girl named Sara Crewe, who lives in London with her mother. When Sara's father enlists in WWI, the headmistress, knowing she will not receive any more money, forces the girl to become a servant.

The third movie that I would recommend is '300'. This epic 2004 action film directed by Zack Snyder tells the story of King Leonidas and the 300 Spartan warriors who fight against Xerxes and his massive Persian army.

Based on the user's preferences and the genres listed, I would recommend "The Right Stuff" (1983) directed by Ron Howard.

"The Right Stuff" is a historical drama that tells the story of the United States space program from its inception in the late 1950s to selection of the Mercury 7 astronauts in July 1961. The film covers the development of the space program, the testing and training of NASA astronauts, the selection of the Mercury 7 astronauts, the launch of Mercury 7 spacecraft, the entry of Mercury 7 spacecraft into Earth's gravitational field, the re-entry of Mercury 7 spacecraft through Earth's atmosphere, and the impact and recovery of Mercury 7 spacecraft from its impact on Earth.

The film stars Tom Hanks as Chuck Yeager, Margot Kidder as Jane Watson, Bill Paxton as Jack "Canute" Ireland, James Whitmore as General D. Eisenhower, and Scott Glenn as astronaut Alan Shepard.

The film was released in November 1983 and received positive reviews from critics, who praised the performances of Tom Hanks, Margot Kidder, Bill Paxton, James Whitmore, and Scott Glenn, and the historical accuracy of the film's portrayal of the United States space program.
According to its ratings on websites such as IMDb, The Right Stuff has a rating of 8.1 out of 10, which means that most people who have seen this movie think that it is good.
